HDG.FS.content: the thinking here [Greek thought]: tautological thinking: primordial sense of phenomenology, prior to any distinction btwn theory/praxis > in philosophy there are only paths (Wege), in sciences only methods > to understand phenomenology: path that leads away to come before…, “lets that before which it is led show itself”: a phenomenology of the inapparent > now you can understand: there were no concepts for Greeks
HDG.FS.linkedContent: the thinking here [Greek thought]: tautological thinking: primordial sense of phenomenology, prior to any distinction btwn theory/praxis > in philosophy there are only paths (Wege), in sciences only methods > to understand phenomenology: path that leads away to come before…, “lets that before which it is led show itself”: a phenomenology of the inapparent > now you can understand: there were no concepts for Greeks

HDG.DL.content: [back to path of question of hermeneutics] hermeneutics als Beiwort to “phenomenology,” means the interpretation itself [not hermeneutics usual meaning] > explaining etymology of hermeneutics will help clarify Heidegger’s intention (Absicht) w/ experiment (Versuch) of phenomenology > Japaner points out Heidegger has now dropped both words [along his path] > not done to deny phenomenology, but to abandon (lassen) my path of thinking to namelessness > which can’t be successful > because public requires rubric (Titel)
HDG.DL.linkedContent: [back to path of question of hermeneutics] hermeneutics als Beiwort to “phenomenology,” means the interpretation itself [not hermeneutics usual meaning] > explaining etymology of hermeneutics will help clarify Heidegger’s intention (Absicht) w/ experiment (Versuch) of phenomenology > Japaner points out Heidegger has now dropped both words [along his path] > not done to deny phenomenology, but to abandon (lassen) my path of thinking to namelessness > which can’t be successful > because public requires rubric (Titel)

HDG.OHF.content: [Heidegger on modern forms of ontology vis phenomenology] only through phenomenology that ontology corresponding to it established on secure basis (sichere Problembasis): only in this manner that the consciousness-of-, the “of which (Wovon),” the object character of a being (der Gegenstandscharakter des Seienden) as such, becomes visible (sichtbar) > wide sense of phenomenology includes ontology > but, in such ontology, meaning of being (Seinssinn) never posed, unknown to it, genesis of meaning remains closed off to it > which field of Being is never asked
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [Heidegger on modern forms of ontology vis phenomenology] only through phenomenology that ontology corresponding to it established on secure basis (sichere Problembasis): only in this manner that the consciousness-of-, the “of which (Wovon),” the object character of a being (der Gegenstandscharakter des Seienden) as such, becomes visible (sichtbar) > wide sense of phenomenology includes ontology > but, in such ontology, meaning of being (Seinssinn) never posed, unknown to it, genesis of meaning remains closed off to it > which field of Being is never asked

HDG.OHF.content: how dialectic places itself above phenomenology: 1) best phenomenology can do: define appearance of Spirit in its 1st stage 2) dialectic alone can penetrate irrational > it’s true, phenomenology is 1st stage of immediate knowledge—but only from point of view of dialectic [nothing can be decided here, dialectic already presupposed] > phenomenology does place limit on knowing (is that a defect?)
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: how dialectic places itself above phenomenology: 1) best phenomenology can do: define appearance of Spirit in its 1st stage 2) dialectic alone can penetrate irrational > it’s true, phenomenology is 1st stage of immediate knowledge—but only from point of view of dialectic [nothing can be decided here, dialectic already presupposed] > phenomenology does place limit on knowing (is that a defect?)

HDG.OHF.content: [phenomenology beyond dialectic] dialectic directionless (richtungslos) when no Grundblick in direction of (auf) the subject matter (Sache), a rationality testing/proving itself by looking this way (i.e. not dialectically) [Heidegger uses rationality affirmatively here?] > all dialectic lives from table of others, Hegel: “this traditional material” (Plato, Aristotle) “extremely importance source, indeed a necessary condition [and] presupposition to be gratefully acknowledged” (Science of Logic) > dialectic is double-sidedly un-radical: 1) lives from hand to mouth 2) eloquent about readymade material
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [phenomenology beyond dialectic] dialectic directionless (richtungslos) when no Grundblick in direction of (auf) the subject matter (Sache), a rationality testing/proving itself by looking this way (i.e. not dialectically) [Heidegger uses rationality affirmatively here?] > all dialectic lives from table of others, Hegel: “this traditional material” (Plato, Aristotle) “extremely importance source, indeed a necessary condition [and] presupposition to be gratefully acknowledged” (Science of Logic) > dialectic is double-sidedly un-radical: 1) lives from hand to mouth 2) eloquent about readymade material

HDG.OHF.content: phenomenology can only be appropriated (zugeeignet) phenomenologically, i.e. through demonstration (Ausweisung), & not by repeating Grundsätze or following Schuldogmen > we’re constantly deceived about things in themselves: once the conscience of philosophy, “now a pimp (Zuhälterin) for the public whoring of the mind (öffentlichen Hurerei des Geistes), fornicatio spiritus” (Luther)
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: phenomenology can only be appropriated (zugeeignet) phenomenologically, i.e. through demonstration (Ausweisung), & not by repeating Grundsätze or following Schuldogmen > we’re constantly deceived about things in themselves: once the conscience of philosophy, “now a pimp (Zuhälterin) for the public whoring of the mind (öffentlichen Hurerei des Geistes), fornicatio spiritus” (Luther)

HDG.OHF.content: [method warning re: phenomenology] not about obtaining/delivering propositions/dogmas re: Dasein, generating a philosophy around it > rather, a special investigation w/ view to right direction of looking toward genuine phenomenon
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [method warning re: phenomenology] not about obtaining/delivering propositions/dogmas re: Dasein, generating a philosophy around it > rather, a special investigation w/ view to right direction of looking toward genuine phenomenon

HDG.OHF.content: [history of phenomenology] phenomenon, distinctive mode of being an object (shows itself, not merely represented): being-present as an object from out of itself (das von ihm selbst her Präsentsein eines Gegenstandes) > certain modes of the object that aren’t genuine can still be factically dominant
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [history of phenomenology] phenomenon, distinctive mode of being an object (shows itself, not merely represented): being-present as an object from out of itself (das von ihm selbst her Präsentsein eines Gegenstandes) > certain modes of the object that aren’t genuine can still be factically dominant

HDG.OHF.content: [bracketing of phenomenology—deconstruction of Heidegger’s destruction?] Husserl’s phenomenology: “where are the objects about which logic speaks and how are they for it?” > Brentano characterized consciousness as intentionality, a concept that arose in Middle Ages, though it had narrower meaning then: volitional being-out-for-something and going-toward-it (das willentliche Aussein auf etwas) (orexis)
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [bracketing of phenomenology—deconstruction of Heidegger’s destruction?] Husserl’s phenomenology: “where are the objects about which logic speaks and how are they for it?” > Brentano characterized consciousness as intentionality, a concept that arose in Middle Ages, though it had narrower meaning then: volitional being-out-for-something and going-toward-it (das willentliche Aussein auf etwas) (orexis)

HDG.OHF.content: Husserl’s object didn’t change, but the how of interrogating/defining it did, question of access (Zugangsfrage): a descriptive method (not a constructivist one) > “phenomenon” not primarily a category, but deals w/ how of access/grasping/safekeeping (Verwahrung), phenomenology (initially) nothing more than mode of research/inquiry (Weise der Forschung): “addressing (Ansprechen) something just as it shows (zeigt) itself and only to the extent that it shows itself”
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: Husserl’s object didn’t change, but the how of interrogating/defining it did, question of access (Zugangsfrage): a descriptive method (not a constructivist one) > “phenomenon” not primarily a category, but deals w/ how of access/grasping/safekeeping (Verwahrung), phenomenology (initially) nothing more than mode of research/inquiry (Weise der Forschung): “addressing (Ansprechen) something just as it shows (zeigt) itself and only to the extent that it shows itself”

HDG.OHF.content: Heidegger describes how transcendental idealism entered phenomenology [via Dilthey?] &, as a countermovement, traditional realism > no one asked whether epistemological questions are meaningless in phenomenology
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: Heidegger describes how transcendental idealism entered phenomenology [via Dilthey?] &, as a countermovement, traditional realism > no one asked whether epistemological questions are meaningless in phenomenology

HDG.OHF.content: [on the wishy-washy industry of phenomenology] George circle, Keyserling, anthroposophy, Stein, Phenomenology of Mysticism—“Beware of all this!” > “the ruin can no longer be halted!”
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [on the wishy-washy industry of phenomenology] George circle, Keyserling, anthroposophy, Stein, Phenomenology of Mysticism—“Beware of all this!” > “the ruin can no longer be halted!”

HDG.OHF.content: phenomenology needs to be understood in accord w/ its possibility, possibility means: taking it up (ergreifen) in its being & developing (ausbilden) it (what’s sketched out in advance [vorgezeichnet] re: its possibilities)> in phenomenology, objects encountered by a definite manner of looking toward them and seeing them (bestimmtes Hinsehen), one does so already oriented toward them, an already-being-familiar (schon Bekanntsein), the sedimented result (Niederschlag) of having heard about them
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: phenomenology needs to be understood in accord w/ its possibility, possibility means: taking it up (ergreifen) in its being & developing (ausbilden) it (what’s sketched out in advance [vorgezeichnet] re: its possibilities)> in phenomenology, objects encountered by a definite manner of looking toward them and seeing them (bestimmtes Hinsehen), one does so already oriented toward them, an already-being-familiar (schon Bekanntsein), the sedimented result (Niederschlag) of having heard about them

HDG.OHF.content: [why phenomenology requires destruction] in any discipline, we’re face to face w/ how things stand at the moment [i.e. how the public world views them] > their showing-themselves (Sich-zeigen) can be so restricted/fixed (festgelegt) by tradition, the inauthenticity goes unnoticed, taken for authentic: one passes off a contingency (Zufälligkeit) as an in-itself, takes a covering up (Verdeckung) for Sache itself > need to get beyond position started from (Anfangsstellung) & arrive at grasp of subject matter free of covering up (zur verdeckungsfreien Sacherfassung zu kommen) > the tradition must be dismantled (abgebaut)
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: [why phenomenology requires destruction] in any discipline, we’re face to face w/ how things stand at the moment [i.e. how the public world views them] > their showing-themselves (Sich-zeigen) can be so restricted/fixed (festgelegt) by tradition, the inauthenticity goes unnoticed, taken for authentic: one passes off a contingency (Zufälligkeit) as an in-itself, takes a covering up (Verdeckung) for Sache itself > need to get beyond position started from (Anfangsstellung) & arrive at grasp of subject matter free of covering up (zur verdeckungsfreien Sacherfassung zu kommen) > the tradition must be dismantled (abgebaut)

HDG.OHF.content: “phenomenon” will become truly earnest matter if it turns that to be in mode of covering-up-itself (Sich-verdeckens) & self-veiling (Sich-verschleierns) [which constitutes object of philosophy] belongs to Seinscharakter des Seins [withdrawal of Being]: phenomenology in radical sense
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: “phenomenon” will become truly earnest matter if it turns that to be in mode of covering-up-itself (Sich-verdeckens) & self-veiling (Sich-verschleierns) [which constitutes object of philosophy] belongs to Seinscharakter des Seins [withdrawal of Being]: phenomenology in radical sense

HDG.OHF.content: phenomenology as discipline, coming to a fundamental “Sache,” which bears w/in itself (bei sich selbst trägt) possibility of research & how to do it
HDG.OHF.linkedContent: phenomenology as discipline, coming to a fundamental “Sache,” which bears w/in itself (bei sich selbst trägt) possibility of research & how to do it
